comments.commentBody:
"We have here a populist man of the people playing the role of friend to the big banks and enemy of the long-term unemployed. What can I tell you? The guy is extremely popular in Massachusetts. Maybe it’s because he drives a truck"

There are a lot of contradictions and inconsistencies in the right wing republican messages. But they are doing pretty well in the polls, for what reason I can't fathom. I find it really hard to believe the country is in favor of returning the failed policies of the big business apologists to power. I find it really hard to believe they will be rewarded for rooting for the country to fail. I find it really hard to believe that the populace wants to apologize to BP, blame the unemployed for their own plight, and raise taxes on the poorest rather than the richest among us.

But that is what appears to be the current situation. Rather than understanding that the stimulus temporarily averted a great depression, the country wants to blame Obama for a lack of full prosperity. Rather than blame our problems on Bush's eight years, many seem to want to blame our plight on Obama's year and a half.

I don't get it.

But the phenomenon is real. The republicans have no program at all, yet are expected to make massive gains in November. It is time for the progressives and the democrats to figure out why and do something about it.

And the answer is NOT to try to pressure Obama into becoming a left wing extremist...

This would be funny if it weren't so sad...damn sad.

Our leaders don't lead and our congress is incapable of legislation. And frankly I couldn't care less if they are all unhappy and overly tired...they simply aren't accomplishing anything for us, who pay their salaries and benefits.

Obama was left with an ungodly recession but it hasn't gotten any better and he has no one to blame but himself and his democratic leadership.

We have is 2 wars that we can't afford, fighting for minerals in Afghanistan and oil in Iraq while we have millions of unemployed here at home who can't feed their families leading to multitudes of starving children.

And the republicans are thinking of nuking ants while the democrats can't rein in guys like Nelson (speaking of herding cats) to pass decent reform or extend unemployment benefits, our most basic charity for those less fortunate.

We need a complete change of both leadership and attitude. The sooner the better because if things keep going like they're going, there will soon be riots in the streets that will make the '60's look tame and breadlines that will make the '30's look prosperous.

So.

Obama wants to take more of my money.

And Boehner wants to give me less of it back.

Thing is, John. I'd expected this from Barack.

And given his predecessor's performance - I'd voted for him anyway.

From you, it's a shot in the side of the head with a pipe.

What's the privatized version of this. If, at the end, I have too much in my 401 or IRA, you gonna grab that, too?

As someone who's paid in at the high end of Social Security "contributions" each year, I knew:

> The return was terrible

> Others who paid in less were going to get disproportionately more.

But, the point was, I knew. Those were the rules of the game.

Your grab doesn't sound like a Democrat grabbing.

In fact, it doesn't sound like anything I've heard before.

Except perhaps nails on a chalkboard.

Is this what you say at all those fundraisers?

Perhaps you should take a rest.

..."“Every Republican I talk to says John Boehner, by 5 or 6 o’clock at night, you can see him at bars. He is not a hard worker,” said Scarborough."

WELL, thank you Joe Scarborough! Now I know why my husband and I were in shock as we watched a replay of the "interview" with John Boehner. He was puffy eyed and somewhat incoherent--which I deduced was because of an impaired ability to think critically and speak articulately off the cuff. "Oh, I dunno, said my astute husband, I think he is either drunk or high!" I thoroughly disagreed with this assessment, because everybody knows that the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives would not come to an interview--ah, drunk!

Mea Culpa. I watched the interview again, and John Boehner, like Scott Brown, is certainly not the sharpest pencil in the pack. However, that droopy eyed, slurry look was most likely not caused by the Republican Kool Aid he drinks with every meal!

Perhaps since Richard Mellon Scaife became such good friends with Hillary Clinton during the Democratic primary campaign of 2008, he has lost enthusiasm for his Republican pals. Otherwise, why would he let one of the few Leaders of the Republican Party who actually holds elective office (as opposed to Rush Limbaugh, Sarah Palin, Newt Gingrich & Rudy 9/11 Giuliani) self-immolate on the pages of his own fine journal?

My very favorite remark Leader Boehner made during the interview was this:

"Ensuring there’s enough money to pay for the war will require reforming the country’s entitlement system."

This is quite a bon mot. Who would have thought John Boehner could so pithily capture the essence of Republican policy: Wage war, and make poor old people pay for it.

No use complaining about Scott Brown's working for the rich & squeezing the poor. Clearly, his orders come from the leadership. Mr. Popularity got the memo. Sen. Brown's financial reform dance is proof he even read it. Or perhaps he's taking private lessons from Prof. Grassley of health reform renown. Brown's latest moves suggest he will go far in the Republican Party -- if he can get himself re-elected.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

Please, the media jumps on the back of every top player who has a "down phase". The pundits who had written off Federer after Aussie '09 and Nadal after French '09 were proven wrong both times. Federer will be a force atleast for another year or two before his body betrays him. Also, calling Del Potro slower on court than Soderling and Berdych is ridiculous. The author needs to perhaps refresh his memory of the '09 US Open finals.

Rafa's talent as a tennis player is well proven - he is the very deserved #1 player in the world - but he continues to astound me over and over again with his mental strength. His will to win is unmatched and even when faced with huge hurdles, he stays in the moment and gives his all. What a player. Vamos Rafa.

Boehner is a jerk.  Most conservatives don't like him.  But, that is no help at all to the rapidly declining poll numbers of Obama and the Democrats.  The Democrats controlled Congress when the financial catstarophe occurred.  The Democrats controlled Congress for the great giveaway bank bailout.  Obama and the Democrats did the auto bailouts , the ridiculous cash-for-clunkers, and the wasteful ,trillion dollar so-called  stimulus.  And, Obama has been the best friend to the bankers of any President in history.  The people will make their displeasure known in November.  I look forward to the results.

1. Tevez vs. Mexico - power, placement - Golazo
2. Villa's first time 40 yard shot, punishing a poor keeper clearance
3. Suarez's curling effort off the post in the 80th minute
and... I'm a bit of a homer
4. LD to win the game in stoppage time - only stoppage time goal that has won the game
5. LD vs. Slovenia - acute angle, roofing it - really rare to see a professional keeper duck.
Tshabala's for sure. Definitely the best performance by an announcer (by far!) of all of them. Golazo in synchrony with the dance!
Not to mention that even Federer is out!

Why not take that $150 million and provide DIRECT loans to homeowners ALL OVER AMERICA instead?   I don't think it's fair that these loans are only available to homeowners who live in enlightened localities.  I'd love to get a loan like this.
Oh, for pity's sake.  Get on board and up to speed, Fannie and Freddie.  NOW.  We ought to be putting solar panels on every roof we can.  We should have done it years ago.

I'm glad to see some acknowledgement that opportunities in France is a lot easier to come by if you are named Pierre than if you are named Rachid. But this seems like a problematic solution. As other commentators have mentioned, you can't map the American notion of affirmative action onto a society that refuses to track any statistics based on ethnicity, but is still permeated by the notion that anyone from an immigrant background remains an outsider to the nth generation. Equally problematic is the mindset that "tout est joué" by the age of 20, and that performance on a single test in late adolescence (the French system is much more test-oriented) determines the rest of your life. So this is a step in the right direction, but there are many steps left to take.

Ha! The French meritocracy.  I used to work for a financial firm based in London.  We had marketing operations in every European country... except France.  Why?  We weren't (a) native french speaking and (b) white.  Thus, we had no chance.  France needs to ditch the conceited fallacy that the country is any type of "meritocracy".

odysseus wrote: "I disagree with NS who writes, "In America, anyone can rise up from the gutter and become one of the richest men in the country." That's just an American ideology (and why is the goal to become one of the richest -- men!). It happens in France -- but when it happens, the French do tend to insist much more on how remarkable it is."

------
I don't doubt there are self made millionaires in France. What I doubt is there are many who rose from the bottom to the top in the spectacular fashion that you see in America. Why do I use getting rich to make my point? Of course there is more to life than money, but the article points out how only a few children of the elite get into the best schools and get the best jobs and are set for life. How many North Africans and Blacks have become millionaires in France? It is almost a mission impossible. Even among the Whites in France it is not easy unless you are some sports figure or entertainer.

In America, one can easily bypass the system and make something of yourself. It is something deeply rooted in America that if you work hard and take risks you too can make it to the very top. It is not an ideology, it is a fact that happens everyday. I say in France you can work as hard as you want and take as many risks as you want, but you still probably won't make to the top. A place that in France seems pre-determined by birth. The reason why the French always seem amazed and impressed that someone is a millionaire is because it rarely happens. Especially from the lower classes. In America being a millionaire is so unremarkable that you have to become a billionaire to impress anyone.

I too, have been a student in the French system (the Sorbonne) and I just want to point out that on the level of WHAT IS TAUGHT, the French meritocracy-or pretense of one-in the sense that it has never provided equal access still has lots going for it.  I never worked so hard as as student or learned so much as a student than when I studied  at the Sorbonne-and I did it for next to no money when compared to college tuition in the U.S.  I am happy to see that the French are opening up an class based closed system at the top, but I would also love to see more discussion on the fact that students in the US are increasingly shut out by economics-and that the US has an elite based on money alone.  Culturally there is no comparison in the way the French value knowledge.  I became a fluent French speaker and student of French in part because in France being interested in books, eager to think, and to study the humanities was supported in an absolute manner.  I was always respected for my efforts.  I remember feeling so down when I was graded in the French manner 11 points out 20 on a test.  I went home to my French concierge, and when she saw the score, she congratulated me, saying that just to break 10 in the French system represents lots of work.  When I graduated from the the program, our whole class was treated to free coffee at a cafe, and we were publically congratulated by the proprietor, after a ceremony in which I was kissed on both cheeks and treated like royalty-simply for having been successul in a summer program at the Sorbonne.  People on the street would always compliment me, just on hearing I as a student studying French at the university level.  Contrast this attitude with what I have faced in an American context:   After getting an M.A. degree in European History, I could only get a teaching job if a coached a sport-often that was the first question at interviews.  I have been  told on more than one occasion that my interest in the humanities is less than useless.  My father was criticized for "allowing" me to study history by his colleagues at work-such it was not practical.  France and European school systems subsidize learning "unpractical" subjects, just as European health care is subsidized.  As a result, my intellectual development was valued in its own right.  This is a French strength, that goes beyond the problem of social mobility and class.  Right now the American system is being strangled by a strict markeplace definition of value-as a result of this definition-children are without insurance, and education is only valued as a means to getting job.  In France, all children are insured-and knowledge is of infinite value.  I just don't see why this European difference is so often ignored in these online debates comparing the U.S. to European countries.  When it comes to social security, and education, Europe is ahead, because its citizens accept that they must pay more taxes, that society is one unified whole, and that health and education are the most important investment a society can make in its citizens.  Tragically, the average American citizen pays far less in taxes, but can be denied health coverage, and educational opportunity.

PM wrote:"I am a statistician, have lived in the US for a while, and would like to challenge you to prove your statement (especially the word "anyone"). How about printing this statement on a T-shirt and walking around in a foreclosed-ridden neighborhood? Perhaps around Bedford Stuyvesant in Brooklyn? I would expect that your life expectancy would be of, say, 30 minutes. Not much longer. No, frankly, please, don't do it."

----
Oh dear. I seem to have started something with my posting I never meant to. I did not mean anyone literally can become a millionaire. I meant unlike France where those who rise to the top and become the big bosses and millionaires are predetermined, not so in America. I stand by that. If anyone in France wants to prove me wrong they should give me a list of the "anyones" who became millionaires. "Anyones" meaning people from all walks of life. Black, White, poor, rich, whatever. There are over nine million millionaires in America. That should tell you all you need to know about how "anyone" can become a millionaire in America. I am always amused when people always point to the bad things in America to challenge facts present to them. Yes, there are also very poor and suffering people in America.

I think it's more social class than race. In the grandes ecoles one will find north africans and blacks, but these were raised in their respective countries and belong to the upper class, there are not the sons and daughters of former immigrants who spent their life working in factories. One would hardly find any white with undeducated parents in the grandes ecoles as well.

"Yikes! What does that mean? Should you never download an app, then? How are you supposed to make that decision?"

Ummm, how about with your brain? Stop, read what it says, and ask yourself if you really mind what it has access to. If you don't, download the app. Or read the comments on Marketplaces--in my experience, if users think that the app unnecessarily accesses private data on something, they'll say so. Use their reactions in part to gauge your own.

"¶Skype comes preinstalled on the phone — but it doesn’t work over Wi-Fi. In fact, you have to turn off Wi-Fi completely. Bizarre."

You can use Fring and Skype Out over wifi quite nicely. I know--I'm in Europe and I used it to call my mom for her birthday.

Dave Brown, #2: '"we’re witnessing one seriously crazy game of leapfrog" -- and we all win!'

Yeah. It's a good thing we are not landfills.
Thanks. For someone looking to go in this direction, you've provided a lot of excellent information. I appreciate it.
How is the security warnings a bad thing? It lets you know in advance what information the app will be using.

Too many generalizations. Android is on OS, not a phone. The different manufacturers make, customize and sell phones. Some will be high end and others not. For instance, the HTC Aria is smaller than the iPhone unlike the Motorola Droid.

You complain about the Droid when similar annoyances occur on the iPhone without mention, e.g. failure to rotate in all apps, lack of unified messaging and calendaring, Skype only worked under Wi-Fi and NOT on the 3G network. They are valid irritants but you need to be more consistent.

The open source motto is "Release early, release often." Android is doing this and if this confuses you, then you should stay in a walled garden.

David,
I loathe back ended compliments. "The best android phone" From your own review Mr. Pogue you said "If you who crave power, speed, flexibility, dropless calls an almost-Imax screen and Verizon’s network (as opposed to Sprint and its similar Evo), the Droid X is a big, beautiful contender"

I own an Iphone but I found this review very unfair to the Droid X. By all account the Iphone 4 has a major flaw. It's not very good as a phone. It's has basically been relegated to Ipod touch status with some phone capabilities due to a verifiable antenna problem. Now from that we can deduct,as logical people, that the phone that does not drop calls and is fast and powerful would be the "best phone" Not just the best Android Phone Mr. Rogue, but the best phone period.

This is my opinion as an owner of 3 Iphones and 1 Ipod touch and many more mac products. I am proof that you can buy Apple products and appreciate them without being blinded by prejudice toward other products.
